Steps to reproduce:

1. Read Bug 711144.


Actual results:

It is totally unclear which "edge cases" are meant by the sentence

   "There are edge cases where it may pick libxul or other libraries 
   from another gecko directory that is in LD_LIBRARY_PATH"


Expected results:

Explain what the edge cases are. IMHO LD_LIBRARY_PATH is always set intentionally. Hence I cannot imagine any user setting LD_LIBRARY_PATH in order to get the path low precedence. Therefore Bug 711144 shall be backed out.

comments.text: The main edge case is when starting firefox or any other gecko-based application from another gecko-based application that sets LD_LIBRARY_PATH to add its own directory. Having that first is a recipe for failure. Likewise for any other path the user may set intentionally.

comments.raw_text: The main edge case is when starting firefox or any other gecko-based application from another gecko-based application that sets LD_LIBRARY_PATH to add its own directory. Having that first is a recipe for failure. Likewise for any other path the user may set intentionally.

Is there a specific reason why LD_LIBRARY_PATH is used instead of the $ORIGIN keyword?

http://docs.oracle.com/cd/E18752_01/html/816-5138/dev-env-4.html

“$ORIGIN Keyword

However, in other environments, the file system namespace is not so well controlled, and developers have resorted to using a debugging tool — the LD_LIBRARY_PATH environment variable — to specify the library search path in a wrapper script. This is unnecessary, because the $ORIGIN keyword can be used in path names specified to the linker -R option. The $ORIGIN keyword is expanded at runtime to be the name of the directory where the executable itself is located. This effectively means that the path name to the library directory can be specified using the pathname relative to $ORIGIN. This allows the application base directory to be relocated without having to set LD_LIBRARY_PATH at all.”
